description.narrative:
Project title: Support the strengthening of local capacities to prevent and Managing crises and disasters in two municipalities of Tillaberi Duration: from 1 June 2013 to May 2014 Intervention area: 02 municipalities of Tillaberi region in Niger. Directs beneficiaries: The direct beneficiaries are estimated at 619 people with at least 50% of women are members of Vulnerability Monitoring Observatory (OSV) and community early warning system and response to crises (SCAP-RU), staff and board members of FCMN Niya, members of sub regional committee for prevention and management of disasters and food crises (CSR / PGCCA), and populations of beneficiary villages micro projects. Others beneficiaries: The indirect beneficiaries are 619 people with 50% women.It is population, agro pastoralists and fishermen of 02 municipalities project intervention. The project aims to improve the functioning of community and communal vulnerability monitoring and emergency response system at 02 municipalities of Niger through capacity building of key stakeholders in a sustainability perspective. The expected outcomes Four (04) main outcomes are expected from the implementation of this project Outcome1: FCMN NIYA is able to support the community and communal tracking devices vulnerability in the prevention and management ofcrises and disasters. This is to strengthen the capacity of FCMN NIYA on the prevention and management of emergencies to provide qualitative support for OSV and SCAP / RU to play the role of international NGOs have always assured. The main activities to achieve this result are training staffs of FCMN NIYA on key issues related to emergencies such as humanitarian standards SPHERE, Live stock emergencies guidelines and standards (LEGS), Participatory analysis of capacity and vulnerability (APCV), logistics, finance and administration in emergency, etc. Outcome 2: community early warning systems of 02 municipalities are operational, sustainable and integrated national early warning system.
Main activities that will help achieve this result are (i) restructuring and / or revitalization of OSV / SCAP / RU, training and equipment and support, organization of exchange visits. Outcome 3: The 02 municipalities coveredby the program in FCMN NIYA intervention area are able to manage crises and disasters
Activities that support this outcome are (i)support the achievement of APCV at municipal level; (ii) develop contingency plans that reflect the specific needs and vulnerabilities of women and provide anappropriate response to them, (iii) support to the implementation of community micro projects to strengthen preparedness to crises and disasters. Outcome 4: The national early warning system (SAP) accepts and integrates information of 4 SCAP-RU through02vulnerability monitoring observatories (OSV). The main activities of this result are (i) organize advocacy for active participation of SAP and its branches in the activities of OSV and SCAP / RU, (ii) support the operation of the Advisory Committee, (iii) support the activities of management of CSR / PGCCA communal structures and community, (iv) support the production of quarterly newsletters on the vulnerability at the departmental level, (v) train municipal and departmental stakeholders on charter prevention and management of food crises.

participating-org.narrative: Fédération des Coopératives Maraîch du Niger (FCMN-Niya)

In 1994 eleven horticulture producers# co-operative set up the Association of Market Garden Producers (APROMANI), to counter the lack of attention paid to them by the National Union of Co-operatives and the marketing problems of agriculture products theyencountered. In 1996 APROMANI became the Federation of Market Gardeners of Niger (FCMN). It was registered in 1998. Until 2001 its activitieswere based at its executive office, mainly related to structuring the co-operatives. Since 2001 it has had a cadres specialised in agriculture who provide a sustained technical assistance. From 2001 to 2007 FCMN has worked with three-year strategic plans and annual operational plans. A self-analysis of the organisation has identified gaps in reforms for women#s leadership in the Federation#s co-operatives. It currently has 118 members from all over the country, with a total of 30,000 individual members, of whom 9,000 are women. Since its founding the Federation has initiated structuring activities to strengthen its organisation, including 27 shops forinputs, one pilot centre for marketing fruits and vegetables in Niamey, 120 field workers and six sites for producing onion seeds. It strives to contribute actively to the development of the horticulture sector andfood security in Niger through integrated activities, like the cereal banks supporting schools and health centres, as well as school gardens/ The organisation#s mission is to contribute to improving the living conditions of market garden producers, and tostrengthening their production capacities and the guarantee of proper prices. Its vision is of an autonomous structure of, for and by market gardeners. The institutional objects are (a) to seek solution to the problems in production, the supply of inputsand agricultural materials, product marketing, funding, and trainingof members, and (b) to promote the capacities of the market gardeners# organisations in Niger to become a force for mobilising local resources and advocacy. In order to realise its mission FCMN organises its intervention around the following strategic themes: supply of agricultural inputs, support and advice (training, working out training materials, organisation of producers and capacity building of their organisations), production, marketing, food security, fundraising and management.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands
